repnme.cdata!:
Starting over - Rebuilding Papua New
            Guinea's Gazelle Peninsula after volcanic eruption

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about
            rebuilding Papua New Guinea's Gazelle Peninsula after
            the volcanic eruption. After fifty years of dormancy, two
            volcanoes in Rabaul, Mount Tavurvur and Mount Vulcan,
            erupted in September1994 for the third time in 100 years.
            Around 30,000 residents lost their homes and about
            two-thirds of them sought permanent resettlement away from
            hazardous areas. Second Gazelle Restoration Project helped
            to rebuild infrastructure from scratch in several
            communities, relocating thousands of villagers to safer
            ground, providing them with new water supplies, and a new
            school for their children. The project also ensured the
            sustainability of social and economic well-being while
            minimizing the adverse impacts of future volcanic eruptions
            on lives, property and livelihoods in the Gazelle Peninsula.

docna.cdata!:
Starting over - Rebuilding Papua New
            Guinea's Gazelle Peninsula after volcanic eruption

Starting over - Rebuilding Papua

TF039793-PAPUA NEW GUINEA - PNG PROJECTS,TF037628-ASIA REGION - PNG, PLCY

repnme.cdata!:
Papua New Guinea - Second Gazelle
            Restoration Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Gazelle
            Restoration Project for Papua New Guinea (PNG) were as
            follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was moderate, Bank performance was satisfactory, and
            Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: involvement by several donors with
            different financing and disbursement procedures and
            information requirements imposed a considerable
            administrative burden on Gazelle Restoration Authority (GRA)
            administrative and engineering staff, in particular. In
            addition, reserving Bank-financing for critical components
            for improving the quality of life for displaced communities
            will have lessened the adverse impact of problems
            experienced with the European Union (EU) financing mechanism
            by accelerating provision of basic services in relocation
            sites as well as intensifying the dialogue on social and
            livelihood aspects. The assessment at appraisal indicated
            that operations and maintenance (O&M) on project assets
            will be administratively and financially manageable by all
            responsible agencies. The adverse impact on provincial
            revenues replacement of the provincial sales tax by the
            national value-added tax apparently undercut the
            province's longstanding tradition of adequate O&M,
            something which could not have been anticipated. The
            province's present limited revenue authority and
            dependence on government transfers highlights the need for a
            thorough review of the current arrangements. The use by GRA
            of a contract administration manual and enhanced risk
            management measures project restructuring in 2005 was
            effective in minimizing further cost escalation and
            implementation delays. While, implementation delays in the
            early years were largely out of the GRA's control,
            these tools and techniques are transferable and could
            generate major efficiency gains on development projects
            generally in PNG.

repnme.cdata!:
Papua New Guinea - Second Gazelle
            Restoration Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall objective of the Second
            Gazelle Restoration Project is to support the Medium Term
            Restoration Program (MTRP) of the East New Britain
            Provincial Administration. To achieve the goals of restoring
            social and economic wellbeing to the people of the Gazelle
            Peninsula, the overall program and Bank-financed project
            will support the following six components. The first
            component, quality of life improvement in displaced
            communities, will include: land mobilization; infrastructure
            and utility services; social and public safety services;
            community development; and economic support. Transportation
            infrastructure, utility infrastructure, social services,
            public safety, economic support, and government
            administration reform comprise the second component,
            Kokopo's consolidation as the provincial capital. The
            third component, Rabaul's restoration as a regional
            port, will deal with land management; port-related
            infrastructure and facilities rehabilitation; and
            restoration of essential utilities, infrastructure, and
            public services. Utility infrastructure and social services
            for the North Eastern Gazelle Peninsula are the fourth
            component while the fifth is institution building for longer
            term development planning. The final component will contain
            design and supervision of project components for the first
            phase of the project and design of components planned for
            implementation during the second phase.

Papua New Guinea - Second Gazelle

repnme.cdata!:
Papua New Guinea - Second Gazelle
            Restoration Project : resettlement action plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Gazelle Restoration Project
            seeks to restore the self-sufficiency and wellbeing of the
            East New Britain people to the level prevailing prior to the
            1994 volcanic disaster. The resettlement action plan applies
            to project affected persons including plantation workers and
            their families whose rights, standard of living,
            subsistence, and income earning capacity are adversely
            affected through the acquisition of assets for sites for
            voluntary relocation. A census of the affected population
            including an inventory of their assets lost will be
            undertaken to from the basis for planning and implementation
            of a relocation and compensation action plan. Based on the
            concensus and inventory of losses, a time bound action plan
            with a budget will be prepared. All compensation and
            relocation assistance including assistance to find
            comparable jobs must be completed before the site is opened
            for settlement by beneficiaries from the high risk villages.
            Progress of implementation and outcomes of the relocation
            and compensation action plans will be reported regularly.
